results.title: Reciprocating behavior (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Science Research Association, Phil Content and Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Interaction in the Multicultural Classroom”.
Because we are all dependent on each other, a voluntary exchange of personal ideas and emotions allows us to develop as individuals. Reciprocating behaviour in the classroom enables the pupils to develop, to become both receiver and giver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Science Research Association, Phil Content and Patricia Heffernan-Cabrera

results.title: Recently 2
results.brief_description: In Jochen Kuchen’s playful animated short ‘Recently 2’ a man undertakes a new medical procedure that allows him to see everything inside his body. What he discovers however is an inner world brimming with memories, hopes, dreams and disillusionment. Beautifully conveyed by blending various styles of animation, this evocative work ultimately explores not the building blocks of the body, but those of the soul.

results.title: Receding wetlands
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Robert Horne and Ken Taylor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
Describes the feeding habits of waterbirds in swamp lands south of Darwin, particularly the delicate ecological balance of this environment. Photography: Ian Warburton

results.title: Rebel music: the Bob Marley story
results.creator_credit: Antelope Films, Thirteen, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Jeremy Marre
results.brief_description: This documentary traces musician Bob Marley’s rise from the violence and poverty of the slums of Jamaica to become a cultural icon, symbol of Rastafarianism, black politics and civil rights. Initially Marley had difficulty in getting his music heard in Jamaica, but eventually his sound grew in popularity. Whilst travelling in America, Marley was influenced by images of the Afro-American uprising of the civil rights movement, causing his writing to become much more political. Upon his return to Jamaica Marley soon turned to Rastafarianism - a specifically Jamaican movement, banned under Colonial rule, that married black consciousness with spiritual awareness. Being a Rastafarian revolutionised Marley’s music and politics, making him a powerful force for the black human rights cause, as well as a political ally and danger to the leaders of the country. This documentary includes interviews with Rita Marley (his widow), Lee Scratch Perry, The Wailers, lovers, producers, collaborators, friends and colleagues in the music industry, politicians and family members. Contains archival footage of Marley, film clips, interviews and live shows. Songs include: Rebel music, Judge not, Soul rebel, Corner store, Put it on, One love, Stir it up and Its alright.

results.title: Rebel angel
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, RM Productions and John Read
results.brief_description: A documentary made to celebrate the bicentenary of the birth of British painter, J.M.W. Turner. It brings together Turner’s sketchbooks, watercolors, oil paintings and the actual locations where he painted, into a comprehensive account of the diverse nature of his creativity. Suitable for secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Rebel
results.creator_credit: Phillip Emanuel Productions, Phillip Emanuel and Michael Jenkins
results.brief_description: Rebel (Matt Dillon) has done enough. He wants out. The war has taken its toll; it’s wounded him, confused him and now it has sickened him. Rebel is deserting. He is on leave in Sydney, Australia. A guy called Tiger Kelly can arrange passage on a cargo ship back to America. All it takes is money. But that’s not a problem because Rebel wants to get home - whatever the price. Rebel is now a runaway, a fugitive. His fate is sealed. If he gets caught he gets shot. What Rebel needs is a place to hide out. Kathy (Debra Byrne) has that place.
